query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Benigna volontade in che si liqua 2 sempre l’amor che drittamente spira, 3 come cupidità fa ne la iniqua,
4 silenzio puose a quella dolce lira, 5 e fece quïetar le sante corde 6 che la destra del cielo allenta e tira.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Gentle goodwill in which is dissolved 2 the love that always inspires rightly, 3 as lust does in the wicked,
4 imposed silence on that sweet lyre, 5 and made the holy strings quiet, 6 which the right hand of heaven loosens and tightens.
**Old English:**
1 Blīðe willa on ðǣm sīe līðeð 2 symble ðæt lufu ðe rihte blǣwð, 3 swā gītsung dēð on ðǣm unrihte,
4 swīgendne sette ðā swētan hearpan, 5 and ðā hālgan strengas gestilde, 6 ðā ðæs heofones swīðre læteð and teohhoð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Come saranno a’ giusti preghi sorde 8 quelle sustanze che, per darmi voglia 9 ch’io le pregassi, a tacer fur concorde?
10 Bene è che sanza termine si doglia 11 chi, per amor di cosa che non duri 12 etternalmente, quello amor si spoglia.
query.result:
**English:**
7 How will those substances be deaf to just prayers, 8 which, in order to make me want 9 to pray to them, were in agreement to be silent?
10 It is right that he should grieve without end 11 who, for the love of something that does not last 12 eternally, strips himself of that love.
**Old English:**
7 Hu ða gesceafta ðara ðe syndon rihtwisra bene, 8 ða ðe ðurh ða geornunga ðe ðu woldest ðæt ðu ða bæde, 9 ðurh ða stilnesse ðara ðinga ðe ðu bæde wæron geþafunga?
10 Wel bið ðæt ðæt ðone unendelice reowð 11 ðe ðurh ða lufe ðæs ðinges ðe ne mæg ðolian 12 ðone ecan lufe ðæs ðinges forlæt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Quale per li seren tranquilli e puri 14 discorre ad ora ad or sùbito foco, 15 movendo li occhi che stavan sicuri,
16 e pare stella che tramuti loco, 17 se non che da la parte ond’ e’ s’accende 18 nulla sen perde, ed esso dura poco:
19 tale dal corno che ’n destro si stende 20 a piè di quella croce corse un astro 21 de la costellazion che lì resplende;
22 né si partì la gemma dal suo nastro, 23 ma per la lista radïal trascorse, 24 che parve foco dietro ad alabastro.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Like through the tranquil and pure air 14 a sudden fire darts now here, now there, 15 moving the eyes that were fixed,
16 and seems a star that changes place, 17 except that from the part where it kindles 18 nothing is lost, and it lasts but a short time:
19 such from the horn that stretches to the right 20 at the foot of that cross ran a star 21 from the constellation that shines there;
22 nor did the jewel depart from its band, 23 but along the radial line it sped, 24 which seemed like fire behind alabaster.
**Old English:**
13 Swa swa ðurh ða gesæliȝan and ða clænan lyft 14 gæð nu her, nu ðær ðæt hrædlice fyr, 15 styrende ða eagan ðe ðær fæste stodon,
16 and ðinceð steorra ðe his stowe awent, 17 būton ðæt of ðære healfe ðær hit onæled is 18 nawiht ne losiað, and hit ðeah hwile ðurhwunað:
19 swylc of ðæm horne ðe on ðone swiðran healf stent 20 æt ðæs rodes fót ran a steorra 21 of ðære tungolcræfte ðe ðær scineð;
22 ne awende ða ðæt gim ðone streng, 23 ac be ðære radlican liste hit ðurhferde, 24 ðæt ðuhte fyr æfter ðæm ælfene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Sì pïa l’ombra d’Anchise si porse, 26 se fede merta nostra maggior musa, 27 quando in Eliso del figlio s’accorse.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Thus Anchises' shade drew near, 26 if our greatest muse deserves faith, 27 when in Elysium he noticed his son.
**Old English:**
25 Swa ða Ancises sceadu genealæhte, 26 gif ure mæste mægðe hyht bið, 27 ða he on ðam Elisyum his suna oncneow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 «O sanguis meus, o superinfusa 29 gratïa Deï, sicut tibi cui 30 bis unquam celi ianüa reclusa?».
query.result:
**English:**
28 "O my blood, O grace of God 29 poured down upon me, when was it ever 30 that the gate of heaven was opened twice for you?".
**Old English:**
28 "Eala min blod, eala oferfletende 29 Godes gife, hwanne wæs hit æfre ðe 30 ðæt heofona geat wære getwæmed twiwa?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 E quando l’arco de l’ardente affetto 44 fu sì sfogato, che ’l parlar discese 45 inver’ lo segno del nostro intelletto,
46 la prima cosa che per me s’intese, 47 «Benedetto sia tu», fu, «trino e uno, 48 che nel mio seme se’ tanto cortese!».
query.result:
**English:**
43 And when the bow of the burning affection 44 was so discharged that speech descended 45 toward the mark of our intellect,
46 the first thing that was understood by me 47 was, "Blessed be you," it said, "three and one, 48 who in my seed are so courteous!"
**Old English:**
43 And ða ðæs hatan lufan boga 44 wæs swa afylled, ðæt ðæt word astah 45 ongean ðæs modes getacnunge,
46 ðæt forme word ðæt ic ða gehyrde, 47 "Gebletsod ðu," hit cwæð, "ðreo and an, 48 ðe on minum sæde eart swa milde!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E seguì: «Grato e lontano digiuno, 50 tratto leggendo del magno volume 51 du’ non si muta mai bianco né bruno,
52 solvuto hai, figlio, dentro a questo lume 53 in ch’io ti parlo, mercè di colei 54 ch’a l’alto volo ti vestì le piume.
query.result:
**English:**
49 And he continued: "Your long and welcome fast, 50 spent reading from the great book 51 whose pages never change from white to brown,
52 has been rewarded, my son, here in this realm 53 where I speak to you, thanks to her 54 who clothed you with wings for your lofty flight.
**Old English:**
49 And he followed: "Grateful and distant fasting, 50 drawn reading from the great volume 51 where white nor brown never changes,
52 you have solved, son, within this light 53 in which I speak to you, thanks to her 54 who clothed you with feathers for the high flight.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Tu credi ’l vero; ché i minori e ’ grandi 62 di questa vita miran ne lo speglio 63 in che, prima che pensi, il pensier pandi;
64 ma perché ’l sacro amore in che io veglio 65 con perpetüa vista e che m’asseta 66 di dolce disïar, s’adempia meglio,
67 la voce tua sicura, balda e lieta 68 suoni la volontà, suoni ’l disio, 69 a che la mia risposta è già decreta!».
query.result:
**English:**
61 You believe the truth; for the lesser and the greater 62 of this life look in the mirror 63 in which, before you think, your thought expands;
64 but so that the sacred love in which I watch 65 with perpetual gaze and which satisfies me 66 with sweet desire may be better fulfilled,
67 let your voice, confident, bold, and joyful, 68 sound forth your will, sound forth your desire, 69 to which my response is already decreed.
**Old English:**
61 ðu gelyfst ðæt soðe; for ða læssan and ða maran 62 ðyses lifes locað on ðam spegle 63 on ðam, ær ðam ðe ðu ðence, ðin ðoht spryt;
64 ac forðæm ðe ðæt halige lufu on ðam ðe ic wacige 65 mid ecere gesyhðe and ðe me aset 66 mid swetum gewilnungum, ðæt hit sy bettre gefylled,
67 ðin stefn fæst, bald and blide, 68 cyðe ðinne willan, cyðe ðinne gewilnung, 69 ðam ðe min andsware is nu gecweden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Io mi volsi a Beatrice, e quella udio 71 pria ch’io parlassi, e arrisemi un cenno 72 che fece crescer l’ali al voler mio.
query.result:
**English:**
70 I turned to Beatrice, and she heard 71 before I spoke, and smiled at me a sign 72 that made the wings of my desire grow.
**Old English:**
70 Ic me wende to Beatrican, and heo ða gehyrde 71 ær ðam ðe ic spræce, and heo me bletsode mid hire blice, 72 ðæt min willa weox ðæs ðe swiftor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Poi cominciai così: «L’affetto e ’l senno, 74 come la prima equalità v’apparse, 75 d’un peso per ciascun di voi si fenno,
76 però che ’l sol che v’allumò e arse, 77 col caldo e con la luce è sì iguali, 78 che tutte simiglianze sono scarse.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Then I began thus: "Affection and intellect, 74 as soon as the first equality appeared to you, 75 became of equal weight for each of you,
76 because the sun that illumined and burned you, 77 with its heat and with its light is so equal, 78 that all comparisons are inadequate.
**Old English:**
73 Þa ongan ic ðus: "Wilnung and geþoht, 74 swa swa ðæt æreste efen eow æteowde, 75 ða wurdon ge ðurh ðæt efenhefe ðurh ðone anan,
76 forðæm ðe ðæt sunne ðe eow onlihte and ontende, 77 ðurh ða hætan and ðurh ðæt leoht is swa efen, 78 ðæt ealle gelicnessa sindon to lytle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Ben supplico io a te, vivo topazio 86 che questa gioia prezïosa ingemmi, 87 perché mi facci del tuo nome sazio».
query.result:
**English:**
85 I humbly beseech you, living topaz, 86 that you adorn this precious joy, 87 so that you may satisfy me with your name.
**Old English:**
85 Ic bidde ðe eaðmodlice, ðu lybbende topazion, 86 ðæt ðu ðeosne wurðfulne gefean mid gemman gefrætwie, 87 ðæt ðu me mid ðinum naman gefylle.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 «O fronda mia in che io compiacemmi 89 pur aspettando, io fui la tua radice»: 90 cotal principio, rispondendo, femmi.
query.result:
**English:**
88 "O my foliage in which I took delight, 89 while still waiting, I was your root": 90 such was the beginning of her response to me.
**Old English:**
88 "Eala ðu min leaf on ðam ic me gefeonde, 89 ða ða ic ðe abide, ic wæs ðin wyrttruma": 90 swylc wæs ðære andsware ordfruma, ðe heo me sealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Poscia mi disse: «Quel da cui si dice 92 tua cognazione e che cent’ anni e piùe 93 girato ha ’l monte in la prima cornice,
94 mio figlio fu e tuo bisavol fue: 95 ben si convien che la lunga fatica 96 tu li raccorci con l’opere tue.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Then he said to me: "He from whom your lineage is said to come, 92 and who has circled the mountain for a hundred years and more 93 in the first cornice,
94 was my son and your great-grandfather: 95 it is fitting that you should shorten his long toil 96 with your deeds.
**Old English:**
91 Þa cwæð he to me: "Se ðe man segð 92 ðinne mægðe and ðe hund gearena and ma 93 on ðam forman hring ymb ðone munt hafað faren,
94 min sunu wæs and ðin eam wæs: 95 wel gebyreð ðæt ðu ðone lange geswinc 96 mid ðinum weorcum him gewyrce."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Fiorenza dentro da la cerchia antica, 98 ond’ ella toglie ancora e terza e nona, 99 si stava in pace, sobria e pudica.
query.result:
**English:**
97 Florence, within the ancient walls, 98 from which she still rings the bells for terce and nones, 99 lived in peace, sober and chaste.
**Old English:**
97 Florentia innan ðære ealdan byrig, 98 ðanon heo gyt tæcð tierce and none, 99 heo wæs on sibbe, sobre and clæne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Non avea catenella, non corona, 101 non gonne contigiate, non cintura 102 che fosse a veder più che la persona.
query.result:
**English:**
100 She had no necklace, no crown, 101 no pleated skirts, no belt 102 that was more visible than her person.
**Old English:**
100 Heo næfde nænne halsbeorh, nænne beag, 101 nænne golde gimmas, nænne gearwe, 102 ðe wære to geseonne ofer ða gesceaft.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Non faceva, nascendo, ancor paura 104 la figlia al padre, che ’l tempo e la dote 105 non fuggien quinci e quindi la misura.
query.result:
**English:**
103 She did not, being born, yet cause fear 104 to her father, for time and dowry 105 did not flee from the measure here and there.
**Old English:**
103 Ne geworhte, ða heo geboren wæs, ða gyt ege 104 fæder hire, ðæt tima and teoh ða gyt 105 ne flugon ðanon and ðanon ða gemetu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Non avea case di famiglia vòte; 107 non v’era giunto ancor Sardanapalo 108 a mostrar ciò che ’n camera si puote.
query.result:
**English:**
106 There were no gambling houses; 107 Sardanapalus had not yet arrived 108 to show what can be done in a bedroom.
**Old English:**
106 Næs ðær hlafatu husa wægnhreð; 107 næs ðær gyt Sardanapalus 108 to æteowian ðæt ðe on bedde gedafenað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Non era vinto ancora Montemalo 110 dal vostro Uccellatoio, che, com’ è vinto 111 nel montar sù, così sarà nel calo.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Montemalo was not yet surpassed 110 by your Uccellatoio, which, as it is surpassed 111 in the ascent, so it will be in the descent.
**Old English:**
109 Nis Montemalo ða gyt ofercumen 110 fram ðinum Uccellatoio, ðe, swa he ofercumen is 111 on ðam upstige, swa he bið on ðam niðerstige.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Oh fortunate! ciascuna era certa 119 de la sua sepultura, e ancor nulla 120 era per Francia nel letto diserta.
query.result:
**English:**
118 Oh fortunate ones! each one was certain 119 of her burial place, and still none 120 in France was deserted in her bed.
**Old English:**
118 Ea, eadige! æghwylc wæs georn 119 hire byrgena, and nænig wæs gyt 120 on Fræncum on bedde forlæten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Saria tenuta allor tal maraviglia 128 una Cianghella, un Lapo Salterello, 129 qual or saria Cincinnato e Corniglia.
query.result:
**English:**
127 She would have been considered a marvel then, 128 A Cianghella, a Lapo Salterello, 129 Who now would be Cincinnatus and Cornelia.
**Old English:**
127 Heo wære ða wundur to wene, 128 An Cianghella, an Lapo Salterello, 129 ðe nu wære Cincinnatus and Cornelia.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 A così riposato, a così bello 131 viver di cittadini, a così fida 132 cittadinanza, a così dolce ostello,
133 Maria mi diè, chiamata in alte grida; 134 e ne l’antico vostro Batisteo 135 insieme fui cristiano e Cacciaguida.
query.result:
**English:**
130 To such a tranquil, to such a fair 131 life of citizens, to such a trusty 132 citizenship, to such a sweet dwelling,
133 Mary gave me, called in loud cries; 134 and in your ancient Baptistery 135 I was made a Christian and Cacciaguida together.
**Old English:**
130 To swilcre reste, to swilcre fægernysse 131 burgwara lifes, to swilcre treowðe 132 burhwaran, to swilcre swetan wicum,
133 Marian sealde me, gehaten on heanre stefne; 134 and on ðinum ealdan fullwihte 135 wæs ic gecristnod and Cacciaguida ætgædere.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Moronto fu mio frate ed Eliseo; 137 mia donna venne a me di val di Pado, 138 e quindi il sopranome tuo si feo.
query.result:
**English:**
136 My brother was Moronto and Eliseo; 137 my lady came to me from the valley of the Po, 138 and from there your surname was made.
**Old English:**
136 Moronto wæs min broðor and Eliseus; 137 min lafdi com to me of Pades felda, 138 and ðanon ðin ofernoma wearð geworht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Poi seguitai lo ’mperador Currado; 140 ed el mi cinse de la sua milizia, 141 tanto per bene ovrar li venni in grado.
query.result:
**English:**
139 Then I followed the Emperor Conrad; 140 and he invested me with his knighthood, 141 so much did he come to esteem me for my good works.
**Old English:**
139 Þa ic folgode þam casere Conrade; 140 and he me gyrede mid his cempum, 141 swa wel he me for ðam weorce weorðode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Dietro li andai incontro a la nequizia 143 di quella legge il cui popolo usurpa, 144 per colpa d’i pastor, vostra giustizia.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Behind them I went to confront the wickedness 143 of that law whose people, through the fault of their shepherds, 144 usurp your justice.
**Old English:**
142 Æfter him ic eode ongean ða unrihtwisnesse 143 ðære æ ðe ðæt folc, ðurh heora hyrda gyltas, 144 eower rihtwisnesse reafiað.
